title: The Creeks Beneath Our Feet
field_artist_s_: Lost Rivers, Rivers Rising, and the River Poets
body:
Lost Rivers is a small group of citizen geographers, researching and mapping long-buried creeks. Newer related projects are Rivers Rising and RAINscapeTO, both social enterprises that connect people to neighbourhood greening projects and eco-gardening job opportunities. Grounded in historical connections of the place to Indigenous, settler, and immigrant communities, Lost Rivers/Rivers Rising travels through time to envision a future for the city that connects us all.

Setayesh Babaei is an Iranian-Canadian artist and designer based in Toronto. During her undergraduate studies at OCAD University in the Environmental Design program, she dedicated her work to the realization of the buried rivers in Toronto and their transformation due to urbanization from waterways to underground sewage systems. Her project explores the history as well as the future of the city’s hydrological system; from the greenbelt to rivers, the “Veins” of our city. Besides her full-time career as a designer at a transportation planning and engineering company, Babaei has been collaborating with the Toronto Lost Rivers for the past two years. She is currently a graduate student at OCAD University where she is continuing to develop her project and expand her research.

John Wilson (born in Youngstown, OH, USA; lives in Toronto, ON, Canada) is an independent community engagement specialist and waterfront advocate. Wilson leads public walks with the Lost Rivers project, a collaboration of the Toronto Green Community and Toronto Field Naturalists, and serves as co-chair of the West Don Lands Committee. From 2000 to 2011, Wilson served as chair of the Task Force to Bring Back the Don, a citizens’ advisory committee of Toronto City Council with a mandate to restore a clean, green, accessible Don River.

Helen Mills (born in Johannesburg, South Africa; lives in Toronto, ON, Canada) is the founder of Lost Rivers, a project of the Toronto Green Community. When she came to Toronto, she noticed a sunken park near her house. Years later she learned that it was a remnant ravine and home to lost Mud Creek. Mesmerized, she wanted to paint blue lines on the street and over buildings, to name the creeks and bring them back to the surface of our awareness. Then the Lost River Walks began through the alchemy of the very first public meeting of the Toronto Green Community (1994). More than 33,000 people have walked on a Lost River since then.

The River Poets

Maureen Hynes (based in Toronto, ON, Canada) has just launched her fifth book of poetry, Sotto Voce (2019). Previous collections have won the Lampert Poetry Prize from the League of Canadian Poets, and were shortlisted for the Pat Lowther and Raymond Souster awards. She has contributed poems to more than 25 anthologies, including twice Best Canadian Poetry in English. Maureen loves the work of writing to and for Toronto’s rivers.

Anita Lahey’s memoir, The Last Goldfish: a True Tale of Friendship (2020), is a finalist for the 2021 Ottawa Book Award. She’s series editor of the annual anthology, Best Canadian Poetry, and author of two Véhicule Press poetry collections (Spinning Side Kick, 2011 and Out to Dry in Cape Breton, 2006), as well as The Mystery Shopping Cart: Essays on Poetry and Culture (2013). Lahey is also an accomplished magazine journalist and ghost writer. She lives in Ottawa, Canada, on unceded Algonquin, Anishinabek territory, where she is becoming well acquainted with a different river, the Rideau, which has quite a different personality (and history) from Toronto’s Don.

Dilys Leman’s documentary-style poetry book, The Winter Count (2014), both presents and disrupts colonial narratives about the 1885 Rebellion and Métis leader Louis Riel. Her poetry and short fiction can be found in literary magazines such as Arc, Grain, CV2, Vallum, and Prairie Fire. Several of her “lost river” poems appear in The Wonder of Water: Lived Experience, Policy and Practice, a volume of scholarly essays published by the University of Toronto Press in 2020. Leman lives in Toronto where she works as a freelance writer and editor and teaches yoga, focusing on techniques to relieve chronic pain and stress.

Maureen Scott Harris is based in Toronto and has published three collections of poetry. Her second book, Drowning Lessons (2004), won the Trillium Book Award for Poetry in 2005. Her poems and essays have appeared in periodicals and anthologies in Canada, the US, Italy, and Australia. “Be the River”, a prayer for the Don, was Arc’s poem of the year in 2002. Her essay “Broken Mouth: Offerings for the Don River, Toronto”, won the 2009 WildCare Tasmania Nature Writing Prize. Scott Harris is grateful to Toronto’s rivers, both buried and visible, for their enduring presence and living connection to the natural world.

Nicholas Power performs in wild places with the River Poets. His published work includes the books “ordinary clothes: A Tao in a Time of Covid” (2020), Tin Dittos (2019), Melancholy Scientist (2014), and The Play of Light in Wychwood (2014), and “Writing on Water” (2013), anthologies including The Boneshaker (2015) and Canada’s 150th (2017), and writing in journals including Bywords, Descant, Rampike, wildculture.com, and ottawater. He has been part of Artfest in Kingston, the Ottawa International Writers Festival, and the 2017 International Festival of Authors in Toronto. He has published over twenty-five different writers as publisher of Gesture Press where his own poetry and one-poem appreciations can be found. He also works as a psychotherapist in private practice in Toronto. gesturepress.com

field_editorial:
Moving up from the shoreline along many hidden waterways and ravine systems, the Lost Rivers and Rivers Rising initiatives, together with the River Poets, share methodologies of tracing histories and relationships underneath our feet. Over three walks as part of the TBA2019 Storytelling program, groups of ambassadors led participants along Garrison Creek, Etobicoke Creek, and the Don River. Offering cross-sectional approaches to the many layers of Indigenous histories of these sites, the contributors also unearthed ways in which colonial treaties and industrialization/urban development have radically shaped the cityscape, combining these insights with on-site improvisation, based on feedback, questions, and anecdotes shared by those present. 

The knowledge shared was of critical significance in the context of Maria Theresa Alves’s TBA2019 commission that sought to literally unearth the buried Harbord Bridge that had once crossed the Garrison Creek. In an act of civic excavation, participants in the night walk along the now buried creek and bridge, filled small linen bags with soil that gradually accumulated in the installation. These waterway walks are retraced here through annotation, archival fragments and documentation, transcription and poetry excerpts from contributors such as Helen Mills, John Wilson, and Setayesh Babaei, the River Poets (Anita Lahey, Dilys Leman, Maureen Hynes, Maureen Scott Harris, Nicholas Power), as well as other collaborators. Bringing together multiple voices, generations, and methodologies, Lost Rivers, Rivers Rising and the River Poets’ watershed ways of doing “fieldwork” and “research” create an awareness of the shifting relations between humans and the non-human over millennia.

title: Everything Is Nerve For Us
body:
Bonnie Devine is an installation artist, video maker, curator, writer, and educator. Using cross-disciplinary iterations of written, visual, and performative practice, Devine explores issues of land, environment, treaty, history, and narrative. Though formally educated in Fine Art at the Ontario College of Art & Design University (OCAD U) and York University in Toronto, Devine’s most enduring learning came from her grandparents, who were Anishinaabe trappers on the Canadian Shield in northern Ontario. Recent public acknowledgements of Devine’s practice include a Governor General’s Award in Visual and Media Arts in 2021, and a Lieutenant Governor’s Ontario Heritage Award and OCAD U’s Award for Distinguished Research and Creative Activity in 2019. Her installation, video, and curatorial projects have been shown in solo and group exhibitions and film festivals across Canada and in the USA, South America, Europe, Russia, and China, including the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Berlin International Film Festival, the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington, D.C., and Today Art Museum in Beijing. An Associate Professor Emerita and the Founding Chair of the Indigenous Visual Culture program at OCAD U, Devine sits on several cultural boards and councils in the United States and Canada. She is based in Toronto.

Luis Jacob is a Peruvian-born, Toronto-based artist whose work destabilizes viewing conventions and invites collisions of meaning. He studied semiotics and philosophy at the University of Toronto. Since participating in documenta 12 in 2007, he has achieved an international reputation with exhibitions at the Corner at Whitman-Walker, Washington, D.C. (2021); Museum der Moderne Salzburg, Württembergischer Kunstverein in Stuttgart, and Toronto Biennial of Art (2019); La Biennale de Montréal (2016); Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, New York (2015); Taipei Biennial (2012); Generali Foundation, Vienna (2011); Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York (2010); Kunstverein in Hamburg and Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery (2008). In 2015, he co-curated the conference This is Paradise: Art and Artists in Toronto with Barbara Fischer, in collaboration with Kitty Scott. In 2016, he curated the exhibition Form Follows Fiction: Art and Artists at the Art Museum at the University of Toronto, with a catalogue co-published with Black Dog Press in 2020.
field_article_contents:
NOVEMBER 24, 2020

PART ONE: EVERYTHING IS NERVE FOR US

Luis Jacob As artists, can we feel confident in our ability to make meaning simply because that's what we do? This reflects on what we're doing here, in this conversation: we bring our knowledge; we don't do anything extra except be what we already are.

Bonnie Devine Luis, you're talking about the power of “the social.” I was here in my little room before we started this meeting, and I felt lacking. I felt inadequate and unprepared. But as soon as we began to talk, a piece was added that allowed me to move more confidently into the material—and that piece was you guys, your thoughts. We're learning so much right now about how isolation has an impact and a cost.

Luis Jacob And the quality of the social matters. There are ways of being social that don't affirm each other's integrity, reality, or knowledge—the quality we develop with each other determines whether we make meaning and heal or repeat existing patterns and damage each other.

Bonnie Devine What is the quality of this very mediated Zoom conversation?

Clare Butcher I often find myself speaking at the Zoom room rather than speaking—or conversing with, or listening to, or listening alongside—others in the digital space.

Bonnie Devine When I first started using Zoom, it was very disorienting, as if Zoom was a barrier to the kind of communication I'm used to. But lately I'm finding a closer relationship to people's faces because I can set the Zoom screen so that the speaker is the entire focus, which provides a different kind of access to what’s being communicated. The speaker’s face is very clear and close, but at the same time, disembodied. They are not situated anywhere. I feel this causes a sense of grief and estrangement. Even though we can get to know each other’s faces and gestures very well, we lose a sense of place. And Luis, you have that virtual background!

Luis Jacob on Zoom with a digital background featuring Will Munro’s exhibition, Inside The Solar Temple of the Cosmic Leather Daddy (2010) at Paul Petro Contemporary Art, Toronto. Screenshot courtesy of Luis Jacob.

Luis Jacob It's an installation by a dear friend of mine, Will Munro. He was thinking about mortality—life after death—and his queer ancestors. He was dealing with brain cancer at the time, and he made a temple with these spider plants—a zone where these living creatures purified the air. I like to put myself in their presence and the energy that the virtual background gives on Zoom. The plants I have around me at home are the offshoots of those plants. This generates a funny mixture of the unreal—the disembodied Zoom virtual-background—and the real, because the plants are an actual part of my home environment.

And Bonnie, I keep looking at the stained glass behind you. We talked earlier about Elwood Jimmy and his project with Vanessa Andreotti, Towards Braiding.1 The stained glass makes me think of a braiding gesture.

David Devine, Stained Glass Braid (2015), glass and lead, 37 x 26 cm. Collection of the artist. Photo by Bonnie Devine. Courtesy of the artist.

Bonnie Devine My partner David made it, experimenting with glass. We have a little glass studio in the basement, and the pandemic could have been the perfect opportunity to do more of that work. But instead, the Covid-19 pandemic has been a time of looking out the window and staring off into space. It's not really been a productive time. There are lots of ideas and imaginings and dreaming and a certain amount of writing, but actual art making is not there for me now. I wonder if it isn't a fear for the future. Why do this if we don't know what's going to happen in the next month or year?

Clare Butcher There is something interesting about quarantine—there being no time anymore, and place being the only thing that remains. Situating ourselves again—that is the challenge. How do we do place in the future?

Bonnie Devine I feel that the wilderness—the place called the Wilderness—has always been a fiction. And the extent of that fictional place has grown exponentially during this pandemic because we are so limited in where we can go. The expanse of the dream environment—an imagined, metaphorical place—has become super important in everybody's mind. But it’s not mapped at all; it’s just out there. And it feels like a wilderness because of the peril of Covid-19. It’s as if we're in the castle of our home. I think the expansion of the wilderness in our consciousness may critically change the way we conduct ourselves socially and will probably hang around for quite a long time after we've all been vaccinated and everything's gone back to normal.

Luis Jacob I remember one of my undergrad students once said, “I'm really interested in Nature,” while showing me a hyper-commercial idea of “nature”—a super-Photoshopped image. I responded, “You know, this is an image.” And they said, “No, no, this is nature!” It was so hard to communicate: “OK, this thing you're showing me—this is a picture on your computer. And, moreover, it's a commercial picture. It's not even a photograph you took—it’s a commercial file that you downloaded from a Google search.”

The kind of fiction matters, the quality. If everything we encounter only becomes a screen for our projections, I feel that we actually become impoverished. Are we dealing with fictions that allow us to enrich and grow and heal, or do they impoverish us and make us disconnected or unrooted?

Bonnie Devine That is the existential problem today! How do we establish the difference between what is other—and what is me and my projections? I think it's all about methodology. It’s critical. It’s part of the “Trump” phenomenon: people are completely involved in their projections.

Luis Jacob Yes, it’s social narcissism.

Bonnie Devine Maybe this conversation can be a methodology for addressing that. It's important to meet each other's differences. For me, recognition and acceptance of difference is a precondition for braiding—which is to say, transformation. We transform each other by encountering each other as different. And that kind of transformation is healing because it’s embodied. It embodies me, and it embodies you. Moving from projection to perception is a tremendous cognitive leap.

Clare Butcher Recently, I was listening to a podcast about deception and the kind of storytelling that's involved in self-deception and the deception of others.2 Neuroscientists are studying how pathological liars function, and how their cognitive processes allow them to operate on a level of self-deception. They also found that self-deceivers are generally happier: to live in the real world requires many levels of self-deception. I'm interested in this aspect of projection and survival.

Bonnie Devine Well, there's the fictional, and there's the delusional. To discern the difference we have to do the qualitative study Luis is talking about. In this age when everything dissolves into the digital realm and the real world becomes dangerous, we have to learn how to differentiate and make choices—evidence-based choices—between the image and the real. We need to educate youth who've grown up only in the digital world—where the wilderness really is a fiction.

Perhaps I have a particular position on this because of my Indigenous background and the way I was taught as a child to be in place—and to experience what Western culture would call the wilderness and realize that it's not me. It's actually something else, an other.

Luis Jacob When quarantine first began in the spring of 2020, I started reading the work of a psychoanalyst named Wilfred Bion who believed that everything hinges on the choice to avoid or to face pain.3 This has become a useful nugget for me. If, at some point in our lives—existentially deep, deep in our hearts—we made a decision to avoid pain, then I think a kind of narcissism emerges. There is no other; it’s just me and my fiction, which I hope will shield me from everything. To encounter pain is based on an idea that transformation is possible.

Bonnie Devine It's so interesting that we're talking about narcissism and the manifestation of ourselves within a world of defences. The choice to encounter pain requires humility—the recognition that we are not in charge. We don't have the power we thought we had. And it requires us to re-examine our world view. What is the position of human beings in the great pyramid of life? Are we on top? Are we the alpha predator? Or are we lower down?

I return to the Indigenous notion that says, “Well, we're quite low down actually”—quite low down on the scale and very, very young in our ability to do things. Artists have something to say about this because one of the things we learn really early on is to sit with the pain and ambiguity of it.

Luis Jacob I suppose that's another fiction we've been taught—that we're individuals, and that it’s up to us to manage ourselves. But, really, we're more like plasma amoebas with each other—we’re very porous and sensitive. Everything is nerve for us. And when we meet each other, we expose our nerves to others who might weaponize this exposure, or pander to it—who might treat this exposure with tenderness, or merely as a tool for getting what they want. The ways that others treat my exposure decides who I get to be and shapes what options I have to deal with them. The word “individual” doesn’t quite capture what we are.

And I don’t want to forget the word “humility,” Bonnie. I guess humility is another word for this amoeba. This tender, highly sensitive thing that we are—this amoeba—it has to approach things with humility. It's not in control. It doesn't have armour around it.

Bonnie Devine Exactly—the amoeba-like beings that we are have no choice but to be receptive. This is an extremely vulnerable position to be in, which is what I think Western culture has armed itself against. How can we perceive (where “to perceive” means “to receive”)? How can we actually receive what is being shown or told to us—rather than mediating it into harmlessness?

PART TWO: IT'S NOT ABOUT READING AT ALL 

Bonnie Devine I’ve come to hate the word, “decolonization.” Lately I’ve noticed Western governmental and academic institutions using “decolonization” to signal the virtuous reorganization of their internal power structures towards equity and inclusivity. These efforts are long overdue of course, but they are not decolonial in themselves and ignore and erase the broader political implications within the Canadian context. I find the process cynical. Leaving that particular objection aside though, an individual’s decolonization process should entail disabling our innate ability to armour ourselves. Questioning, for instance, whether the ownership of things, the circumscribing of tracts of land and declaring them “ours”—whether that transaction allows us to transfer the other into our parcel of being. Of course, it doesn’t. Yet everything in our economic system and our political system tells us that this is what a successful human being does.

Luis Jacob Given the systemic toxicity around us, where do you turn when you need energy? What gives you the resources you need to encounter these things and keep going?

Bonnie Devine I'm quite a private person, so I'm not finding the isolation emotionally difficult to handle. I like a bit of time alone. But other people's thoughts, encountering other intellects and exchanging ideas, taps into a kind of joy and is extremely pleasurable for me. Freud would call this “libidinous”—the libidinous drive to encounter and respond to other people's ideas.

Luis Jacob I completely agree with you. It's libidinal, and it's joy. It's a pleasure that affirms what we’re made of. We’re made to feel this kind of pleasure.

Bonnie Devine, Settlement (2018), diptych, mixed media on two boards, 61 x 45.7 cm (each panel). From Circles and Lines: Michi Saagiig, Art Gallery of Mississauga, 2018. Collection of the artist. Courtesy of the artist.

The first time I heard you speak was during your artist talk for Circles and Lines: Michi Saagiig at the Art Gallery of Mississauga.4 There was a moment when I thought, “OK, I really need to reveal myself to Bonnie. There’s something that is tapping into me.” You said many wonderful things, but one thing stood out for me: “Those grids [on the landscape] are imaginary. The maps are imaginary. The diagrams of the Great Lakes—these are imaginary. Our [Anishinaabe] thinking is similarly imaginary. We construct images of the earth and of ourselves in a similar abstract way.”

I felt grateful to you. The typical way of speaking designates Settlers as abstract, and Indigenous people as connected to the real. I'm cool with that—but I have to wonder what that premise takes away from both sides. Does it take the power of abstraction away from Indigenous people? Does it take the power of reality, or rootedness, or embodiment away from Settler people?

I loved that you were able to say that both of these images—colonial maps and Indigenous images—are abstractions: “Let us compare our mythologies and find where they mesh—and find also where they don’t, and celebrate that. Because that’s beautiful. This was what was at the bottom of my mapping, finding the beauty in that abstraction—the European way of thinking—and then delving deep into myself to find the response—which is similarly abstract.” I realized that, for you, bringing these things together—their encounter—is not merely an abstract exercise. You're making tools. That was when I realized I wanted to hear more of you, Bonnie.

Bonnie Devine and Luis Jacob in conversation at Union Station in the context of Luis Jacob’s installation The View From Here (2019). Photo courtesy of Luis Jacob.

The second time was when we did that Union Station panel together, during the Biennial. Before the talk, I recall you said, “This place—Toronto—brings you joy, Luis. But for me, this place—Toronto—hurts me.” I realized I had to be aware of our differences. We experience things differently and I have to honour this difference in our encounters. As a Settler on colonized Indigenous land, I may well be part of what hurts you about this place. And I need to try—as much as I can—to ensure that the way I am with you is not hurtful. I don't know what that would be, but do you know what I'm saying?

Bonnie Devine Yes, some things are hard. I'm sure some things in Toronto are hurtful to you, too.

Luis Jacob Absolutely!

Bonnie Devine Toronto consciousness makes me scared I’ll say something stupid and fall many notches in someone's estimation and then the conversation will be over. Because there are performance measures and I worry, “Am I going to perform adequately, or am I going to waste this person's time?”

It’s part of the system we live in. But if I decide not to be afraid of this anymore, then I have to deconstruct the competitive thing I struggle with: to have to out-do others or out-do myself. I struggle with this and with entitlement. Am I eligible to be part of this? Do I merit the amount of time I'm taking up? Have I only just repeated what others have said before—which of course I always have?

These situations always make me scared. But curiously, talking intimately about them is also very pleasurable. Part of the pleasure is the fear—being right on the edge of falling into complete disrepute by saying something stupid. It's dangerous, and danger is compelling. If you're an artist, you put yourself in danger before the whole world—and that is the joy of it. If you’re also a teacher, giving your students permission to speak directly to you builds their trust that you will be real about what they want to know. That's an important first step in education, right? Allowing them to risk asking the potentially stupid question.

Luis Jacob It's so true.

Bonnie Devine What gives you energy, Luis?

Luis Jacob Artists give me energy. But what I really mean is people—anybody, including “non-artists,” who take the fact that they're alive seriously as if it's something they actually have to work through and do something with. They create something, and that's how they take their existence seriously—as something they have to contend with. I need that almost minute-by-minute, all the time—this is what gives me energy. People who have a lot of shields placed between their identity and their authenticity—this makes me despondent. People who are in touch with their authenticity, even if it's painful and hard and fucked-up and messy—and do something with it—that's whom I mean by “artists”: simply someone who does something with that stuff. Seeing evidence of someone trying to be authentic in this world—that’s what gives me energy.

Bonnie, you say you hate the word “decolonization.” But can we model what “de-armouring” could look like here, in this conversation, by presenting a model—not analyzing it, but doing it ourselves? I think this improvisatory, non-scripted show-and-tell, call-and-response process will in itself show what “de-armouring” could look like.

Bonnie Devine Yes! If it gives us an opportunity to display our vulnerability right here in the presence of one another's work. Another artist’s work is often, at least at the first stage, entirely inscrutable. And only slowly, through questioning and deep receptivity, can we begin to understand, accept, and eventually make meaning of it. Remembering that the first layer of meaning is always provisional and being careful to leave it provisional so a conversation can develop. It's much deeper than simply knowing how to read an image. In fact, it's not about reading at all. It’s about knowing how to open yourself up to another person's expression and learn through it, with totality.

Luis Jacob There's a passage in a novel by Dionne Brand where she describes the experience of walking in the city.5 She’s talking about Toronto, describing a sort of “sandpapering” we do: we rub against people, rub against each other, and sandpaper each other. She writes about all the lives we carry, all the goals we carry, all the means of protection—the armour we carry—all the images we have to ensure recognition by others. In the sandpapering, all the things we carry spill out on the sidewalk. She writes, “There's so much spillage”—a permutation of existence. She describes people turning to each other, imperceptibly, right on the sidewalk. And, for me, that defines what you said about “de-armouring”—a kind of sandpapering with each other so that all the everyday stuff we try to contain can spill out a little bit. And when we spill with each other, we transform each other.

Bonnie Devine Brand’s idea of spillage reminds me of your notion that we're like amoebas. Its relationality corresponds in some ways with Anishinaabe metaphysics, which describes a big flux—there’s no solid place. There’s no “there” or “here.” Everything is happening in this flux, this tidal flux that Western society teaches us to fight. Flux is the opposite of the individual.

Alexandra Park, Toronto, before demolition (2017). Photo by Luis Jacob.

Luis Jacob Can I share something with you? I took this photograph at Alexandra Park, near Dundas and Bathurst, where I came across a woman who was working on this community garden. She was cultivating this garden in the middle of this residential neighbourhood. For me, this image captures so much about this place called Toronto. I took this photograph in 2017, and in 2020 I returned to see what it looked like today.

Alexandra Park, Toronto, after demolition (2020). Photo by Luis Jacob.

That's how it is now. The whole area has been demolished. There was a row of townhouses in front of her community garden, but they're all gone—and her garden is gone. This is what happens in this city in the space of three years. There's a garden, and then there’s a demolished lot. I see this happening over and over—every day, all the time. There is a cultivated garden, and then it's bulldozed. Then, on the bulldozed land tomorrow somebody will try to cultivate another garden. And a few years later it will be bulldozed, again.

This process happens at the level of urbanization; and at the level of memory, there's an equivalent sense of amnesia. Storytelling is like cultivating a garden, which we do at the level of memory, at the level of imagined feeling. I also see a kind of “bulldozing” that happens when stories are bulldozed in the process of amnesia.

How does this keep happening? There's a cycle of cultivation and disavowal, which for me defines this city. From one perspective, this city is constantly in dynamic flux; from another perspective, however, this apparent flux also constitutes a repetitive, even rigidly compulsive sense of repudiation. This is something that hurts me about this place.

PART THREE: I WANT TO GET MY HANDS ON MEANINGFUL THINGS 

Luis Jacob In the Form Follows Fiction: Art and Artists in Toronto exhibition that I curated in 2016,6 I included Robert Houle's Premises for Self-Rule (1994). For me, it is a landscape painting—a landscape of legislation that circumscribes the relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people.

It starts with the Royal Proclamation, continues with the British North America Act, the Indian Act, and finally the Constitution Act.7 This landscape is real. It’s present right now around me, but it is also a landscape that nobody told me about. Nobody educated me about it. The education I got is amnesia.

Bonnie Devine I believe most contemporary Indigenous art in almost every medium being practised right now is a form of landscape. I think one of the projects of Indigenous contemporary art is to expand the definition of what Landscape Art is in Western art vernacular.

What Robert is painting is not a depiction of a real, geographic, or tangible place. This is a landscape of the mind. It unfolds in a couple of ways. On one level it's like a book, a text-work. There’s text on both leaves of the book. The right side includes Western script and needs to be absorbed as that kind of knowledge. It needs to be read. But we use different parts of our brain to read, and we need to use the same part of our brain to read the colour-field panels on the left side of the painting as we use for the text panels on the right—we need to read both in the same way. We use another part of our brain to read colour—or what we would call aesthetic material. And we need to apply that mode of perception to both sides of the diptych also, precisely because the complex of interactions and transactions that occurs around these treaties is that complex. Robert’s work is entirely engaging every perceptive capacity of our brains.

I think this work in particular depicts this understanding and begins to translate what these treaties represent for Indigenous people—and maybe even for the land itself. Because the Anishinaabek think of the land as an intelligence, a consciousness. So yes, it's a landscape for sure.

Luis Jacob I love what you said about the parts of our brain used to read vocabularies, used to apply to different ways of knowing.

Unknown, The Toronto Purchase (1805), digital reproduction of colour manuscript, 39 × 23 cm. Courtesy of Toronto Public Library.

In Form Follows Fiction, I included the 1805 version of the Toronto Purchase treaty.8 I'm sure the person who drew this document could see the complex reality they were representing. I'm sure they were aware of the geography, the life, the culture, the complex Indigenous economies, and the Indigenous language present in this environment. And yet, they made an image of an empty rectangle. What does it take to know something complex but depict it as an empty rectangle? What does it take to shape your brain in such a way that it knows this place is complex and alive, yet describes it as a “vacant lot”?

The idea of the “vacant lot,” of course, is connected to colonialism: the idea that there was nothing here until I came to put something in it. Obviously, it's a fiction. It's a damaging fiction—but a convenient one for the colonizer. I'm trying to understand what artists do with that.

I also included the work, The 1984 Miss General Idea Pavilion Letterhead (1974) by General Idea, in the form of a blank architect's blueprint, which I installed alongside the Plan for a Settlement of York (1788) by John Collins. I'm thinking about the ideology that was at work when this place was imagined. The blueprint purports to render the imagined thing as real in space.

John Collins, Plan of the harbour of Toronto with the proposed town and settlement, 1788, colour lithograph, 84 × 63 cm. Courtesy of Toronto Public Library.

Bonnie Devine What strikes me is the intellectual or imaginary process it represents. There’s no real manifestation. Even the blueprint paper is dealing with a hypothetical, psychological construction. It reminds me of Carl Beam who said, “I want to get my hands on meaningful things.” This is such a healthy way to put it: I want to get my hands on meaningful things.

Luis Jacob The artist and the ruler—holding the ruler in his hand. Carl Beam’s Burying the Ruler (1989) is literally putting his hand on the mental construct of ruling power that says, “This is real.” If that's how they're treating it—as real—then, as an artist, I can put it in my hand and I can bury it in the ground.

Bonnie Devine Carl completely grasped how theoretical everything had become and how theory had been weaponized. These maps, charts, and blueprints are weaponized depictions that allow the colonists to avoid bloodshed—to completely avoid having to get your hands on someone's throat to wrest their land away. And it's quite a brilliant thing. One of its virtues for the colonials is how cheap it is. It's economically sound not to have to send an army. You don't have to do any heavy lifting; instead, you do it by the stroke of a pen. And they did it all over the world.

So, I go back to Carl’s intent: “The purpose of my work is to get my hands on something real.”

Burying the Ruler was made in 1989. There was a growing understanding on the eve of Oka that led some Indigenous thinkers to realize that this “Canada” wasn’t holding. The term "First Nations" came into the Canadian vocabulary during the 1980s, and the impending 500th anniversary of the landing of Columbus in 1992 inspired new considerations of country, nation, and state—and our relationship to the nebulous figure of the Crown. These things had been papered over—persistently deferred—so we couldn't actually get to the reality of it. They had been papered over by textual works and endless conversations and committees and a lot of noise—so much noise—to prevent us from getting our hands on what was real and meaningful.

Canada’s history is full of examples of various leaders’ attempts to write Indigenous presence out of existence. The 1969 White Paper of Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau and his Minister of Indian Affairs Jean Chrétien was one such an attempt. Fortunately, it was successfully countered by a new generation of Indigenous legal thinkers led by Harold Cardinal. In my view, Justin Trudeau arrived in the Prime Minister’s office completely conversant in what his project was to be—to obfuscate and prevent us from getting to “the real.”

Luis Jacob Thinking about reality and fiction, here’s a juxtaposition of two self-portraits: Carl Beam’s Self-Portrait in My Christian Dior Bathing Suit (1980) and Joanne Tod's painting The Magic of São Paulo (1985). I wonder what it takes to put on a Christian Dior bathing suit. There's humour, or levity, in putting on the bathing suit; but the word “Christian” makes me think of the role of Christian missionary work in the process of colonization. What does it mean for Carl Beam to put on the Christian Dior bathing suit and stand like that, so confidently? And then, to create this self-portrait?

On the other hand, the other self-portrait shows the artist, Joanne Tod, at a gala reception for the São Paolo Biennial—which of course, she wasn't invited to. She's also painted herself on a fictional cover of C Magazine—which, of course, she wasn't really published in.

Joanne Tod, The Magic of Sao Paulo, 1985, oil on canvas, 213.4 × 170.18 cm. Collection of Mrs Pamela Hallisey. Courtesy of the artist.

Bonnie Devine The Carl Beam work is so iconic. About the Christian Dior thing, the Christian covering: it's black. Otherwise, he's nude. And his hair, also black, is completely un-immaculate while that bathing suit is, of course, perfect. I think it's a concise statement about defiance under pressure.

Extremely expensive and very, very clean—he’s got the Christian Dior thing stripped down. Everything looks great. He's standing in that very masculine position—and yet his hair is all the things that could not be entirely cleaned up.

Luis Jacob Bonnie, thank you! When you said that, I felt it.

March 9, 2021

PART FOUR: OR TALK TO SNAKES, FOR THAT MATTER

Luis Jacob To consider all contemporary Indigenous art as landscape is to expand the idea of landscape to include that which is not contained, is uncontainable, and shouldn't be contained—that which exceeds and, in some way, survives the processes of containing it.

Bonnie Devine Absolutely. It refuses to be mediated into harmlessness, which goes back to Carl Beam’s self-portrait. We talked about his hair as the thing the Christian Dior bathing suit couldn't tame. It couldn't be mediated into harmlessness.

And there's something else to talk about here, which is Modernism and the role it plays in simplifying or stripping away—the opposite of what Dionne Brand talks about when she says “sandpapering.”

Modernism is a kind of stripping-away that is vigorously applied to things that are uncomfortable so they can be moulded into more acceptable, easily palatable, digestible forms or categories. To me, that’s what fascism is, too. Modernism has an imperative voice that must be resisted. In so much of his work, Carl is challenging it, even while using the standard forms of Modernist style and inquiry to do so.

Luis Jacob In his print Two Kinds of Power (1992), for example, he depicts the measuring device (an electric metre) alongside the animal (a raven). They’re talking to each other. Two forms of energy: one is a measurable, tick, tick, tick energy; and the other is a different kind of energy, a living presence.

Bonnie Devine Or Einstein's famous equation, E = mc2, placed beside a bumble bee. Carl is pointing out equivalences and non-equivalences to question what we mean by order and to acknowledge expressions of human and non-human rationality. These are crucial thinkings that Indigenous art addresses or, at least, observes.

Luis Jacob I recall the literary theorist Northrop Frye who wrote about "revolutionary monotheism”9 —the religion of the settlers, the colonizers. It's monotheistic, obviously, but also revolutionary. The revolutionary part means that this religious world view makes a cut in time: that was then, and this is now. When you combine monotheism with the idea of cutting time into “then” and “now,” you get a very violent, very powerful gesture towards all kinds of relationships and interconnections. From the settlers’ perspective, existing spirits can only be devils and, therefore, can only be erased, disavowed. Difference cannot be accepted; it can only be destroyed.

And then there's the playwright Tomson Highway who is interested in thinking about the three different ideologies that, in his view, shape Canada10 : Greek, which was polytheistic and had many gods; Christian, which is monotheistic, so one God; and Indigenous, which is pantheistic—God is everywhere and in everything. And he said that only in the Christian story did God give something good to humans and then take it away: “Only in the Christian mythology does the one God, the male God, give the planet to mankind to celebrate, and to appreciate—and then take it away. God exiles humanity from the Garden because a woman chose to talk to a snake. In the other two mythologies, there is no such narrative. The Greeks were never banished from Arcadia, and there is no such story in aboriginal mythology either. This is it. We are still in the Garden, and we are still free to worship trees, water—or talk to snakes, for that matter.”11

I just love that insight—there are different ways of understanding, which do not have to be cut apart in a revolutionary gesture, but which can be considered in relation to each other. The things you and I are talking about, Bonnie—armouring and spillage, narcissistic or vulnerable relationships to the environment, neutralizing difference or actually dealing with real difference—it's not always nice. It can be very risky. But it's not the same as self-shielding, the narcissistic scenario where it's just me and my monomaniacal projections.

Bonnie Devine I'm trying to remember Leanne Betasamosake Simpson’s text that talks in beautiful language about biblical teachings and the Genesis story.12 She asks, what if the fall from grace and the expulsion from paradise never happened? She tells it in a beautiful way by teaching her young daughter—and in fact what happens, of course, is that the young daughter teaches the mother. She proposes the notion that there is no master. Those master/slave, instructor/student hierarchies have been imposed on us by systems we inherited. They are incredibly limiting, and they force us to exclude or exempt ourselves from huge amounts of experience and observation.

Tim Pitsiulak, Bowhead with Beluga Whales (2011), coloured pencil and ink on paper, 73.7 x 246.4 cm. Promised gift from collection of Christopher Bredt and Jamie Cameron. Photo by Craig Boyko. Courtesy of McMichael Canadian Art Collection © Estate of Tim Pitsiulak.

Luis Jacob I think about the giant Tim Pitsiulak drawing of the whale at the McMichael. It has a landscape and two carved faces on its back. And the whale’s eye is like this ancient knowledge, this knowledge that goes so far back. You see the drawing, and you can literally feel it.

The McMichael also has some incredible West Coast pieces from the 1880s in its collection. You read the label and understand that in 1885 the potlatch ceremonies were outlawed. So, you go back to the artefacts and realize that these were probably stolen by the police. This is somebody else's stuff! It’s evidence of the violent colonial process. These carvings were confiscated.

Bonnie Devine Yes, stolen goods. And it wasn’t only the goods that were stolen. They also tried to steal the knowledge about how to make those things by breaking the lineage between the maker and the student. So much had to go underground, and the people who knew—who had that knowledge—were also in some sense criminals because they were carriers of that which had been proscribed.

I think it was Clare who spoke about the pathological liar and what is required psychologically to sustain that level of dishonesty—the complexity that a pathological liar needs to be able to juggle and make everything hang together. We need to talk about this problem of denial and avoidance because this is our karmic problem right now. What we're confronting with Covid-19 demands deep interior learning and analysis—not just to make a vaccine, to make it go away, to sandpaper it off—but actually to abrade ourselves so that we can learn from what has happened.

Luis Jacob You’re talking about two distinct interpretations of Brand’s sandpapering: one that tries to erase all the difficult bits and sanitize difference; and the other, the abrasion that allows exposure and vulnerability but also learning and the capacity to transform.

Bonnie Devine I think about the hypersensitive organism, the really tender thing that we are and that everything is. How do we relate to one another so as to do no harm but, at the same time, not to cosset one another so much that learning cannot occur?

Luis Jacob You said that in the Anishinaabe creation story, humans are not at the top of the pyramid, as they are in the Abrahamic/Christian model. We're the neediest of the bunch.

Bonnie Devine The most pitiful, actually.

Luis Jacob In 2017, I attended a walking tour by Jon Johnson, under the Old Mill subway station on the Humber River. Jon showed us the monumental series of murals by Philip Cote, Jarus and Kwest that depict the Anishinaabe creation story. He said that when humans came on the scene all the other animals had already been created. We were the least prepared, the most naked, and the least knowledgeable. So, we need to learn from the different animals. From one animal, we learn how to be strong; from another, how to be fast. We learn skills by opening ourselves to difference.

And I thought, "Wow, this really fits!” Our pitiful human neediness is a kind of abrasion that opens up our wound—our vulnerability—but it also opens us up to the Other. And that’s transformative. It gives us what we couldn't have generated out of our own willpower.

Jon Johson, First Story walking tour at Humber River Valley (2017). Photo by Luis Jacob.

Bonnie Devine Yes, this is why we call the animals that offer knowledge our Older Brothers, and we address them that way. We ask the animals to take pity on us because we usually don’t know how to manage the wilderness on our own. We need to learn, and they teach us.

This is in the language—in the way we address the animals and the land. Our salutations include the notion that we are less, that we lack, that we need help and support. What this position does to the child growing up is humble her before the enormous power of Nature. Nature is definitely not that Photoshopped, extracted image from the internet your student gave you. It’s an embodied, humbling experience. We are taught this truth right from the get-go.

Luis Jacob The sanitized, abstracted version of the wilderness confounds all our encounters with the real wilderness. Since the wilderness doesn't fit the Photoshopped version we've been given, we are tempted to respond with fearful hostility towards it.

I think about Northrop Frye’s ideas about revolutionary monotheism. If you come to North America—to Turtle Island—with the idea that there's only one version of reality, then every other existing version you find here can only be seen as an enemy. This hostility is the opposite of the humility you're talking about. The wilderness is not a devil you have to armour yourself against—it's actually your older sister or brother! This thing you don't fully know or fully understand, this thing you haven't measured, haven't accounted for, haven't instrumentalized or sanitized—it has knowledge, has perceptions, and has tools of its own...that would, if you could open yourself up to them, help you grow and develop. Far from being the enemy, it's actually the thing you need.

Bonnie Devine Yes, but fearsome also—and perilous, of course.

PART FIVE: A CERTAIN CONSANGUINITY

Bonnie Devine You remind me of an aspect of Anishinaabe grammar that is probably useful in this discussion. Objects in the Anishinaabe language are divided into two orders (similar to French, which uses feminine and masculine nouns). In Anishinaabemowin, we have animate and inanimate. Animate things are identified grammatically by our terms of address—but also by our behaviour towards them—because they are sentient beings (even if they don't meet the criteria of sentience as Western science would define it).

So, we would say that the Great Lakes, for instance, are animate, and we would address them and conduct ourselves with the understanding that they are conscious beings like ourselves—and yet superior to us because they are older. They are more travelled than us. They change their properties readily and wondrously and survive it. They are durable as we are not. They're not fragile. They endure. Reverence to us means we are humble, but not humiliated or debased. In fact, our ability to recognize and acknowledge the difference between ourselves and these objects/beings actually elevates us and allows us to be more comfortable in the world and more accepted and loved in the world.

I've been thinking about this a lot recently, particularly with respect to Covid-19. I’ve been considering the science and the evidence, and the question of whether the virus is alive. Viruses have some aspects that indicate life and yet others that prove it’s not a living organism. It’s something else. Well, what is that something else? We don't have language for this in English. But in Anishinaabemowin, we have language for this kind of being and can find a relationship to it and make space within our cosmology for it.

I think this is what Frye is pointing to: the inability of certain dogmas or philosophies to admit a wider scope of being in the world.

Luis Jacob Yes, I agree. And even within Western traditions, there are counter-traditions that try to describe the things you're talking about. Even in modern art history, even when you look at the most rational-looking art, for instance, a painting by Piet Mondrian. It's actually the opposite of rationality. Mondrian was interested in something he called, “dynamic equilibrium.”13 This was not symmetry, not an artificially imposed order—but a self-generated order that is dynamic, that never stops being dynamic.

I find it fascinating that even the Western tradition, with its dominant world view, also contains its own “othernesses,” the counter-currents within it that have also been sanitized in a way that sandpapers and normalizes the weird edges.

Bonnie Devine And isn't it fascinating that in Western culture at least, art is one of the places where counter-knowledges can live? I have to say it isn't the same in Indigenous art. But Western art does seem to offer an escape-hatch or pressure-valve that allows this stuff to get out.

Now, this is not fully formed in my mind yet, and I hope I will formulate these ideas more before I leave the planet, but I think Indigenous art has a different meaning and a different function. The raison d'être for Indigenous art is not to provide a pressure valve where ideas can be safely released or expelled. It's about the ideas themselves. It’s not about religion, but about a spiritual connection, a spiritual understanding of what Mondrian was trying to point to in his colour-theory work.

Luis Jacob Even within the European tradition, the dominant idea of art is a historically “young” idea. I was reading a book by Hans Belting about medieval art: a time prior to the concept of art that’s now become dominant in the West.14

Art didn't exist in the same way in medieval culture as it did in Renaissance (or modern) culture because in medieval art, an artwork was an object of veneration. The viewer’s relationship to it was not just about looking. We can easily think about this in terms of religion, but I think it was also trying to articulate things that are not necessarily Christian—but about communities developing different ideas about the nature of things.

Bonnie Devine This brings me back to our original discussion months ago about methodology. That art in those contexts—in medieval contexts, and I think to some degree in Indigenous contexts—is a methodology of communication. But communication with what? Well, sometimes it's human to human, but often it's not about the human. Often, it’s communication with phenomena, or with visual information that's coming in. It’s a response. Some people might say it’s prayer, but it’s not really that. And some might say it’s ritual—well, maybe, but extremely personal ritual. And yet it’s there for all to see.

Each of us, in looking at art this way, understands a certain consanguinity—a certain eternity—something that you know. And that is what the art is for, or part of what the art is for. And I think it's such an important point for us because, as you know, Indigenous artists today are attempting to make ourselves understood to the mainstream art world, and we need to be clear about the purpose of our activity—this art and how we come to it. How we look at it. How we may redefine the language and the procedure of looking so that it's not extractive, so that I'm not just consuming this image and somehow monetizing it. Instead, I am allowing it to inflect itself on me so that I am transformed.

Luis Jacob I really believe in that idea of art. What you said about consanguinity... this is what I understand. The idea that what I'm made of, you're made of. A connection to something eternal, something bigger and older and vaster and wilder than I could ever come to measure, or describe, or say. But it's an experience.

At one point in our conversation over these months, we talked about how generation after generation has had to fight against erasure or enforced forgetting. I think these conversations assert a place for those experiences, despite ongoing waves of attempts to neutralize it, sandpaper it right out of existence, bulldoze it, legislate it, erase it.

Bonnie Devine It's as if art, or culture, or whatever this is, is a big muscle. They can try to rub it out. They can try to contour it, or whatever else they want to do with it. But it’s there—it has strength and durability, and it goes past our lifetimes and past our little personal memories. I feel that when we have these moments, when we suddenly see it and experience it, it's as if we've come into contact with that muscle, and it’s surging through us—and we realize then, "Oh, my ego is the illusion, and this is the reality."

This is what humanity consists of—this gigantic wisdom that, thank God, we haven't managed to exterminate.

Luis Jacob I’m visualizing Pitsiulak’s whale again… It's this muscle, this body—and its eye is tiny, but it's the window into this vast, vast intelligence.

Bonnie Devine And the beautiful thing, of course, is that it's true. That whale is a physical being. And those physical beings, they are the carriers of that thing we have no English word for yet.

There is something else we have to try to disrupt: the constant attempt to fictionalize these realities or deny the real truth of them because it's too formidable for us. We talked about this at some point: the fictionalizing capacity of the human being, and how it trips us up all the time because some of what we imagine we've made up, we haven't made up. Some of what comes to us in dreams—in fact, much of what comes to us in dreams—is not a dream. It is an opportunity to experience something from a different perspective.

And that capacity for fiction that was given to us to help us explain a whole bunch of phenomena has actually anaesthetized us against a real connection, a true experience.

Luis Jacob English is not my mother language, but I love the expression it has for having a thought: "It occurred to me." I've always thought it's so accurate because it's not me who makes the thought. It occurred to me. And that's what actual thinking feels like: it occurs to me.

At some level, that sounds so irrational—so “fictional.” There's no way that it makes sense: of course, it's me having the thought. But that's not actually what the experience is like. “It occurs to me” actually describes what it's like to think. If we can pay attention to those things—rather than just brush them away as merely a fiction or a fancy turn-of-phrase—but attend to these things as actual philosophy, then we'd be better off.

Bonnie Devine It's a gift. “It occurred to me” is really saying: “Wow, this thing was gifted to me. I was there. It came. I saw it.”

And also: “Now here it is. I'm not going to co-opt this into something I can claim as my own. I'm going to actually acknowledge that this isn't mine. That I was gifted with this piece of insight.” That’s intellectual honesty, or rather, humility. It's recognizing that when these things “occur” to us, it's, “Wow, something was given.”

Luis Jacob That offers me a new definition because, in my world view—the world view I inherited from my culture—a gift, once it's given, belongs to me. But what you're saying is that once it's been gifted, it's still a gift, it's still there without being owned. That is such a beautiful definition.

Bonnie Devine Yes, it's still a gift! And, you know, you have a responsibility now because it was given to you. You have to carry it, or protect it, or share it.

Luis Jacob And serve as its witness. Earlier, at another conversation, we spoke about Murray Sinclair, we talked about the labour it takes to keep fighting, to keep telling the story against the forces of erasure. But then, it occurred to me, like you said: “Now that I've told you the story, you are the witnesses. You have to do the work with this gift, so no one has to carry the weight of that labour alone.”

The gift is actually the labour that we all have to pick up, as witnesses.

Bonnie Devine That's beautiful. I love it because that also explains what art is. The witnesses to a work of art are in a similar way suddenly beholden to it in a special psychic sense: in memory, but also in action. And this is what gives me hope for the process of making art, or the labour of making art, because it has the potential to lessen the weight by sharing the burden in a very beneficent way, in a curative or rehabilitative way.

It is not the artist thinking this up. It is the muscle of the culture attempting to exert itself in a healing way on the population.

Luis Jacob You mentioned “curative.” This made me think of the word “curator.” There's a sanitized version of the career of a curator, defined as a kind of privileged “chooser”—someone who simply selects. For me, that definition has nothing to do with curating. My idea of curating has to do with this curative idea, which is about witnessing what artists have made and then constructing new constellations—so the stories or the messages can remain active, and alive, and animated, and dynamic.

Bonnie Devine Yes, meaning has curative powers, and making meaning also has curative powers. The curator makes meaning—makes new sentences out of things and allows new choirs of works to emerge and make different kinds of music. The act of making meaning is one of the methodologies we employ to rehabilitate or cure ourselves. I never thought of a curator or the act of curation as curative—but for sure, yes. So, there's something shamanic—here is another word I’ve come to hate because of the exploitation of traditional knowledge by new-age charlatans who call themselves “Shamanic Practitioners”—but yes, there's something in curatorial practice that has to do with medicine.

Luis Jacob In Spanish, my first language, cura means “priest,” and curar means “to heal.” A priest, understood in its Latin root-form, is simply someone who takes care.

It's the medicinal thing you mentioned. Curar, to heal. The root-word for “priest” and “healing” is the same: “care.” It's a shamanic meaning that moves the priest away from the church and into a much older role, which is the person in the society, in the community, who is learning the healing techniques—the meaning-making techniques—that the community itself had developed.

Bonnie Devine This is absolutely what I would say an Indigenous artist is. Someone with a lot of roles: sometimes a doctor, sometimes a teacher, sometimes a container... and sometimes also a learner. Teacher implies learner, and healer implies that which needs to be healed. Because the reason you come to art, I think, is for your own healing. If you scratch an artist deep enough, you're going to find that wounded person who was seeking something that would cure them—and I believe art does that.

field_editorial:
“How may we redefine the language and the procedure of looking so that it's not extractive?” ask artists Bonnie Devine and Luis Jacob—a question that resonates within this publication and in the work of Public Programming and Learning. Jacob shared his extensive personal archive with the Biennial team and artists and proposed a series of talks alongside his two-part installation The View From Here in collaboration with OCAD University. Guest contributors included Simon Vickers, Fadi Masoud and Adrian Blackwell, and Devine, whose decades-long scholarly and artistic inquiries contend with ways to perceive layered histories of Toronto and the treaties and colonial violence that have shaped relationships within it.

In November 2019, Devine and Jacob brought their work into dialogue through two view-finding devices—an antique surveyor’s transit and the sculpture The Riddle (2018)—amidst maps, images, participants, and rush-hour passersby at Toronto’s largest transportation hub, Union Station, giving insight into historical and contemporary acts of surveillance and witnessing, map-making and archiving. The following text is comprised of excerpts from their conversations since Jacob’s first encounter with Devine’s work Circles and Lines: Michi Saagiig (2018) at the Art Gallery of Mississauga, through the pandemic, revealing their commitment to learning through dialogue, and joy in nurturing relationships with peoples, practices, and places.

title: Walking, Talking, and Listening
body: Mark Dudiak (he/him) is a Toronto based artist whose work explores loss through painting, video, and installation. A settler born on Treaty 6 territory in Saskatoon, he holds a BFA from Emily Carr University, Vancouver and an MFA from Concordia University, Montréal. Dudiak has exhibited across Canada and Europe at venues such as ZK/U Berlin, Projet Pangee Montréal, Forest City Gallery London, Access Vancouver, and Nuit Blanche Toronto
field_article_contents:
It’s easy to walk into a public exhibition and feel overwhelmed and intimidated by the art on the walls. No one likes to feel they don’t understand, or that they don’t have the knowledge to engage with something as seemingly complicated as contemporary art.

As an artist myself, I must acknowledge that the forms artists use and the depth of our inquiry can sometimes be at odds with what many of us learn at school about what art looks like and what purpose it serves. But when it’s rooted in the here and now, contemporary art gets us talking about current topics and experiences that affect many of us personally.

The following tunes into the thinking around and experiences of a workshop I led with groups of young people throughout the Toronto Biennial of Art’s Learning Program in 2019 that aimed to amplify participants’ personal experiences of the Biennial exhibition through practices of listening, responding, and collective improvisation.

Workshop participants engage with Mark Dudiak in the context of Embassy of Imagination + PA System’s Sinaaqpagiaqtuut/The Long-Cut (2019). Photo by Sue Holland. Courtesy of the Toronto Biennial of Art.

LISTENING

I only have a loose idea of how any workshop will proceed, my goal is for learners to engage so it can be hard to know what any given group will connect to. Practically this means that I organize my sessions in a modular way, developing multiple exercises for each theme that I want to address. Being responsive is part of creating a space where dialogue can form.

When I walk with a group through an exhibition, I ask what we are looking at. They will often try to skip straight to interpreting the meaning of an artwork but I ask them to explain what they see to me first, to start with the obvious. Once we see some aspect of ourselves or experiences reflected in an artwork, that artwork stops being so opaque. It might look complicated but so is the world and we navigate that all the time—just break it down and note your reactions.I learned this approach from Nicholas Brown, formerly the curator of Red Bull 381 Projects—a small gallery in downtown Toronto that showed Canadian contemporary art by young artists. The gallery was situated in the lobby of Red Bull Canada’s corporate offices and Nick and I had a lot of contact with office staff, many of whom were interested in art but who had received little arts education since high school. Early on, our programming elicited some negative feedback from staff who often felt skeptical about the skills of the featured artists or were fearful of sounding unintelligent by making the “wrong” observations. So Nick initiated small tours through all of our exhibitions. By offering a welcoming space to ask “obvious” questions and express honest reactions to the shows, Nick was able to transform what could have been antipathy from the surrounding staff into appreciation and support. Mostly he just asked questions like, “what’s this?“ and “where are we?”, which worked because that’s often what artists are trying to figure out, too. To be in relation to something in this way means that listening is important, listening to ourselves, that is, honestly, and to what we see in front of us in the gallery.

This conceptual framework maps readily onto the aural: a place of creation that we might understand through our relationship to music but which is still mystifying if explored through field recordings or ambient sound installations. R. Murray Schaefer, a Canadian theorist and composer developed the study of “Acoustic Ecology” in the 1960s while a professor at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver. Along with Hildegard Westerkamp, Barry Truax, Bruce Davies, Peter Huse, and others, Schaffer collected audio field recordings that documented the changing sonic environments that they encountered. These activities supported their “World Soundscape Project” and have helped advance understandings of both the psychological and physiological effects of noise pollution while emphasizing the creative possibilities latent within these sounds.For more on the World Soundscape Project see https://www.sfu.ca/sonic-studio-webdav/WSP/index.html. Key to all of these efforts was an emphasis on listening, as not only a communicative act but also one that inherently grounds us in our spatial context—whether we acknowledge it or not.

Sound situates us at a unique position in space, we are always at the centre of our sonic perception. Through an act of unconscious imagination, we use sound to map and internalize the environment, even the parts of it that are invisible. Educators can exploit this subtle link to engage the imagination by asking learners to visualize audio environments. Before guiding students through the Biennial exhibition, I talked about how hearing passively grounds our experience in a fluid mental model as I played a series of field recordings over a small speaker system. While listening, I’d ask students to draw or write where they imagined themselves to be.

Mark Dudiak, Field Recording: Garden (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

Mark Dudiak, Field Recording: Streets (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

Mark Dudiak, Field Recording: Interior (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

Mark Dudiak, Field Recording: Corridor (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

Mark Dudiak, Field Recording: Workshop (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

Mark Dudiak and workshop participants, Field Recording: Performance (2019). Courtesy of the artist.

When the exercise was complete, raucous discussions usually broke out as the groups compared their visual answers with each other. Generally, students expressed disbelief at what their peers had derived from the same soundtrack.

Through this we began to learn how listening can be a creative act: narrative flowing from our desire to understand. We are not passive receivers. We had created words and ideas from this experience. With this established, we’d head out into the exhibition space where their thoughts and observations could be perceived as creative additions to the wider soundscapes that the artists and curators were proposing, such as Bárbara Wagner and Benjamin de Burca through their video work, RISE (2018), which always encouraged groups to actively engage. This artwork features a host of spoken word artists and musicians based in Toronto who form part of the Reaching Intelligent Souls Everywhere Edutainment (RISE) network, allowing students to see places in their city represented on screen in a beautiful and polished way. With the look and feel of an extended music video and in many ways structured like one with short, stylish vignettes capturing spoken word and vocal performances in subway stations across Toronto, the film was a perfect starting pitch in suggesting that art might not be so inaccessible after all. One group of students began to sing along with artists in the video during a rap battle scene, keeping time with the performances in a joyous impromptu collaboration that sent shivers down my spine. A response to the call—listening leading to creation.

Workshop participants watching Bárbara Wagner and Benjamin de Burca’s RISE (2018). Photo by Clare Butcher.

SOUNDING OUT

The prospect of creating an object, or “take home”, in an arts education context can be a powerful pedagogical motivator. But I’ve found that it can be hard to complete something that youth participants value in the hour or so that I set aside for creation in my workshops—paint takes time to dry, complex projects require tools or a bunch of preparatory steps. It’s important that groups feel they have meaningfully interacted with the exhibited works that can include a lot of media content. With all this in mind, I developed a workshop project that was simple but novel, one that introduced performance and experimental audio arts as accessible and rewarding.

After completing our time with the artworks on display, I would ask the group to join me outside in the parking lot. Using chalk, the learners were encouraged to write a large word onto the land, such as one of the terms generated during the listening session. The collective text on the asphalt would become the instructions for our performance, the script for a story we could create together. Recording on microphones placed on stands around the parking lot, everyone would walk from letter to letter along the chalk words they’d written, shouting each one as they moved along, in their own time and tones. It often became a cacophony of shouting and moving and singing, but the context we’d created for it made everything seem significant.

Workshop participants engage with Mark Dudiak in Walk the Word (2019) exercise in the 259 Lake Shore Blvd E parking lot. Photo by Chiedza Pasipanodya.

The big reveal would come at the very end of the session. With everyone seated as they were when we began the workshop, I’d play their field recordings, our own soundtrack, back to the group over the speaker system. The response was wild, with some participants laughing and trying to identify who said what or smiling shyly when they heard their voices. Usually, someone had whispered something borderline near the mic just to see if they could get away with it and it always caused a scandal. This is the real “take home” from the experience of contemporary art: joy, openness, possibility, modest materials, simple realizations, and imagination.
field_editorial: Artist and educator Mark Dudiak relates his facilitation approach with respect to collective listening and improvising to create meaningful encounters in an exhibition context. Grounded in historically transgressive methodologies of field recording and sound art, Dudiak shares how listening together can help us tune into artists’ practices and interrupt the presumed authority of the ‘expert’ or educator. Throughout his dynamic youth workshop series in TBA 2019, Dudiak put this into practice by inviting participants to listen deeply to artists’ works and words through processes of drawing, conversing, moving and recording. Each workshop culminated in an exuberant performance in which participants created new soundscapes together.

title: Orchard
body: Diane Borsato was born in Toronto where she is an artist, naturalist, and Associate Professor of Experimental Studio at the University of Guelph. She has exhibited and performed her work in major galleries and museums across Canada and internationally. For over ten years she has been collaborating with writer and curator Amish Morrell on Outdoor School, an ongoing series of contemporary environmental artworks. Their new book Outdoor School is available at booksellers now. www.dianeborsato.net
field_article_contents:
Diane Borsato Orchard (2019–) and You Are A Good Apple (2019), apple tasting and conversations. Photos by Yuula Benevolski. Excerpt from Outdoor School: Contemporary Environmental Art (Vancouver: Douglas & McIntyre, 2021). 

There are apples with red flesh, apples shaped like stars and sheep noses, andapples that taste like butterscotch, oranges or roses. There are apples as large asmelons, apples that last just a few hours and apples that look gashed across theskin by a wolf. There are historical Canadian apples that hardly anyone knows thetaste of, as well as twothousand-year-old apples, cultivated since the Roman empire.Eccentric apple varietals are not planted commercially and require dedicatedorchardists to grow them in order for them to continue to exist for future generations.

Orchard is an ongoing public art project aiming to plant rare, historical or eccentricapple varietals in various locations. In 2019, at the Small Arms Inspection Building inMississauga, I planted apple varietals including Pink Pearl, Tolman Sweet, WhiteWinter Pearmain, Kandil Sinap, Black Gilliflower, Hewe’s Crab, Ananas Reinette,Belle de Boskoop, Pedro, Baxter, Williams’ Pride and Sleeping Beauty.

Participating in the work requires a special commitment on behalf of the hostinstitution, to properly maintain the trees on an annual basis and sustain them for theirnatural lifespan. As the orchard grows, it will be an ongoing programmable site ofinterest to a wide public outside of the museum. In contrast to the ‘white cube’ of thegallery, trees in Orchard could be activated by artists and naturalists in various waysaccording to season and weather. The ongoing work is a living, dispersed public artproject—one that combines ecological, aesthetic and gastronomical interests—while challenging traditions of public sculpture and contributing to urban life.

 

To inaugurate the Orchard at the Small Arms Inspection Building, I invited the public to taste historical apples and learn about community orchards. The event included an extensive heritage apple tasting, with orchardist and historical apple collector Bill O’Keefe and other partners including Susan Poizner of Orchard People. More than forty unique and rare apple varietals were available to taste along with free Syrian apple cake catered by Newcomer Kitchen, a non-profit organization that hires Syrian refugee women to cook and share food together. Some of the apples tasted included Pink Pearl, Hornberger Pancake, White Winter Pearmain, Cox’s Orange Pippin, Seek-No-Further, Tolman Sweet, Virginia Crab, Rambo, Pink Princess, Baxter Opalescence, Starsong, Winter Banana, Maiden Blush, Snow, Belle de Boskoop and many more.

The project was co-presented by the Toronto Biennial of Art and Ontario Culture Days. Curated by Dave Dyment. Click here to download the You Are A Good Apple (2019) publication, written by Diane Borsato, with paintings and design by JP King. (PDF)
field_editorial:
ORCHARD is a living and ongoing public artwork by Diane Borsato. Commissioned by the City of Mississauga for 2019 at the Small Arms Inspection Building, twelve rare, eccentric, and historic apple varietals were planted, in a site where weaponry was manufactured during the Second World War; with a nod to the agricultural and colonial history of Mississauga. As a public art sculpture ORCHARD brings people together to learn, admire, share food, and take care of the trees so they and the community around them may thrive. This practice of caretaking imagines a different kind of collectivity—a symbiotic one that considers ecological relation-building between community members, the land, and other non-human beings. We can look forward to building relationships with this work, growing and shifting together over future generations.
