title: The Uncommon Community
body: Fan Wu was born in Baoding, China and is now based in Tkaronto where he is the wick at the tip of the candle of exhaustion. His practice moves between activating language’s intrinsic capacities and exploring language’s unutterable beyond. You can find more of his writing online at MICE Magazine, baest journal, and Aisle 4; or track down Mourning Anthology or Himalayan Musk Rambler, writing collections that he has edited.
field_article_contents:
THE UNCOMMON COMMUNITY

The uncommon community is a potential and real space where slowness and curiosity cultivate a free play for differences between us, and make way for experiences of ecstasy and surprise, intimacy and risk.

The uncommon community is uncommon in the sense of being rare under a cultural regime that restricts value to “having things in common”; this is the basis of neoliberal capitalism, which asks you to collapse your identity into the commodity. Difference is difficult to countenance, so the uncommon community attempts to lay the groundwork of trust and curiosity to bring difference into the full light of consideration.

The uncommon community celebrates not superficial sameness, but moments of unity: moments when we feel like we participate in each other’s stakes of existence. Such a unity is a spiritual gambit: it brings us to that inexpressible, even overwhelming realm of feelings and intuitions.

The uncommon community deems identity too important to be reduced to identity politics. Here identity exists not as a shorthand whereby one assumes knowledge of identity’s supposed categories, but rather is given the full weight of its complexities and indeterminacies, and the disparate, singular ways our identities exist as constantly fluctuating constellations of present experience.

The uncommon community is an idealized vision of togetherness, because our habits and biases trail us wherever we go; we are never free to encounter another person without the vagaries of projection. And yet the uncommon community does not promise the attainment of this ideal, but is an invitation to practise: to slowly peel back our preconceptions and focus our attunement on what’s occurring in the here and now.

The uncommon community thinks of art, and the art gallery specifically, as a fecund backdrop for explorations of uncommonality. The dream is to disengage art from its degradation into mere cultural currency or anxious totems of status.

ART AS EXPERIENCE

Fernando Palma Rodríguez, Cihuapapalutzin (2019), recycled aluminum (beer and soft drink cans), electronics, mechanics, and software. Commissioned by the Toronto Biennial of Art. Photo by Sue Holland. Courtesy of the Toronto Biennial of Art.

For me, art has never been about the discreteness of objects so much as the creative construction of experience as it exists, always in process. “Ordinary” objects are not even objects: they are a pulsation in the eventfulness of experience itself. To identify an object as distinct from others is to analytically isolate it from the emotions, sensoria, and psycho-kinesthetic circuits that are concurrent with our perceptions of that object. When I pass by Dana Claxton’s fireboxes, they fuse with the flow of my vitality, retuning my nervous system and shifting the parameters of my perception—even if imperceptibly, performing this transformation so subtly I don’t cognize it. Objectification is a tactic by our reasoning minds to abstract away from embodiment—certainly useful sometimes, but also overvalued and habitual in how we look at and think about art. And though historical, contextual frameworks are absolutely vital, they can overshadow the simple and direct firsthand experience of artworks, the first shock of their entrance into your body-and-mind; how do we give room for the artwork’s energy to be felt in and for itself?

Part of my work as a Storyteller for the Biennial has been to refocus on experience and experiment with alternative avenues of encounter with art. At one point I gently invited two visitors to sing a song to Fernando Palma Rodríguez’s butterflies and, unbeknownst to me, they were trained in an Arabic classical tradition; the synthesis of those mechanical wings and the melancholy of the music created a miniature, sublime bubble of intimacy at the 259 Lake Shore exhibition venue.

The uncommon community creates a transhuman ecological community that links us to the alien yet animated vital essences of artworks themselves.

MEDITATION: ATTACHMENT

Storyteller Introduction Weekend, slide from presentation by Alison Caldwell (2019). Photo by Clare Butcher.

The gallery is a loaded space, highly charged with social expectations by both artists and visitors alike.

This meditation is intended to clear the psyche, so one can more easily encounter the unexpected without collapsing it back into the recognizable:

Step into the gallery and pause to sit by the entrance immediately as you walk in, so that you’re within the space but only just past the threshold.

Take in the sphere of sensations that the space emanates into you.

Locate your sense of attachments in the space. Perhaps it’s adjacent to any of the following questions:

How do I want to be perceived?

How do I show myself to be engaged?

What will I do with my boredom?

How will I position my body when in the passive act of looking?

How much leisure of time do I have here?

Take inventory of your attachments and anxieties: their content, their intensity, their flavour.

Attachment appears where the body clenches and tightens around the predicted possibility of something happening, of something going wrong.

As you examine your mental-physiological inputs, try to feel out the circuit between Thought and Body.

What tightens when you bring up particular anxieties or attachments?

Before you receive the artwork itself, let your body speak and be heard, so a fuller portion of your nervous system might take part in the experience.

SPONSORS’ WALL

Entrance space at 259 Lake Shore Blvd E, with curatorial statement, Biennial information, and Donors & Sponsorships wall texts (background); and installation by Adrian Blackwell, Isonomia in Toronto? (harbour) (2019) (foreground). Photo by Sue Holland. Courtesy of the Toronto Biennial of Art.

I ask visitors to consider the Biennial’s sponsors’ wall as an artwork. Plastered with logos and donation tiers, these kinds of murals are normally passed over as merely peripheral information, not art proper. But precisely because we habitually graze over the surface of it (and I certainly used to ignore it in my haste to see the art itself), expecting it to bore us, does it hold the most power to hide away the ideologies behind art’s material conditions.

The sponsors’ wall stands as a ledger of abstractions. The glyphs range from the geometric to the figurative, the recognizable to the obscure; no information is given outside the categorization of each logo into different tiers with names like Founding Signature Patron, Founding Innovators, and Founding Visionaries. It faintly reminds me of cultic symbologies, the way these logos mean something only to the initiated, only to those in-the-know: call it a new mysticism of global complicity.

At a deeper level, it speaks to a network of overwhelming interconnectedness that underlines how artistic production is never dissociable from larger forces of enterprise and economy. We must host conversations about art's entanglement with extractivist economies at both a macro-political and a micro-perceptual level. Without pushing a narrative of either redemption or of despair, I leave it up to the viewers to decide how they felt as a part of this tentacular membrane that connects capitalism and artistic creation.

EXTINCTION KARAOKE

Group of participants singing Katy Perry’s "Firework" (2010) with Fan Wu in response to Judy Chicago’s Atmospheres photographs at the Small Arms Inspection Building in 2019. Still from video by Cierra Frances.

Zahra Komeylian and I co-host workshops for school-age children at the Biennial’s Small Arms Inspection Building venue. She works with the therapeutics of clay, inviting the youth into free play and collaborative sculpture making. I ask the children to come up with miniature plays responding to the artwork: Kapwani Kiwanga’s foretold collision between Europe and Africa in Soft Measures (2018–19); Abel and Wilson Rodríguez’s prismatic thickets. My prompt for them is: what does your life look like twenty years from now?

What ends up coming out shocks me: each of the five groups of middle schoolers put on plays about extinction. They choke to death from toxic smog; shoot at each other in simulations of a third world war; burn down to the bone in dramatic conflagrations of climate change end times.

Was I this close to the threat of death when I was in middle school? A generational difference has opened up to me, one far deeper than the usual claims about behaviour and stereotypes. It is an existential difference that warps a young Gen Z’s perception and very possibility of a future. Y2K was the closest analogue in my own life, but it feels like a trifle or a punchline, a blip in the radar compared to the diet of inevitable climate doom on which these children are raised.

At the end of the day we sing, in chorus, moved by the spirit of extinction karaoke, Katy Perry’s “Firework” (2010) to the Judy Chicago Atmospheres photographs—an elegy to an apocalypse all the more real for being seen through kids’ visions.

METHODOLOGY: DESIRE

Curtis Talwst Santiago, I Know Places (2012), mixed-media diorama in reclaimed jewelry box. Photo by Toni Hafkenscheid. Courtesy of the Toronto Biennial of Art.

When facilitating a group, I begin with desire in its broadest sense—although your starting point might exist under a different name, like tendency, or taste, or preference. It’s the way someone’s attention flickers and when they’re able to focus.

Every artwork generates its own energy from its marked difference from the usual world—or its uncanny similarity to it. Curtis Talwst Santiago’s Infinity Series (2012–19) miniatures, these narrative freeze-frames extracted from other worlds, are potently provocative of imaginative tangents; I ask visitors to write poems and stories from them, to dig into the psycho-associative space evoked by these surreal dioramas etched into jewelry boxes. The crucial principle for me as a facilitator is to activate the channel of creativity that artworks already forge, and gently invite art viewers to express their own responses as a continuation of the artwork.

Below is a poem written from a Santiago sculpture by a boy in grade six whose preciousness and precociousness made a gigantic impression on me:

Participant’s poem written in response to Curtis Talwst Santiago’s sculpture, I Know Places (2012), in his Infinity Series (2012–19). Photo by Fan Wu. Poem reads:"A place to go to hit the hay / A lazy place for you to stay /What looks like hay but must be straw / Not easy to build but easy to draw".
field_editorial:
It wasn’t unusual to hear a group of visitors’ voices raised in song—the words to Katy Perry’s “Firework” resounding through the space of the Small Arms Inspection Building, a main Biennial venue—conducted by writer, pedagogue, and one of TBA 2019’s Storytellers, Fan Wu. These spontaneous karaoke sessions within the exhibition space were just one element of the disarming, embodied, and unorthodox methodologies through which groups of students, donors, and institutional reps became co-conspirators with Fan. He also worked closely with other facilitators and Storytellers throughout the Biennial period, showing us how artist-led and collaborative approaches to mediation and learning can ground and shape shared experiences. 

What gets lost in translation? How might improvised actions and conversations, as well as collective thought experiments, invite us to engage with the seemingly unimportant/invisible structural and atmospheric aspects of an exhibition (the wall texts, donor logos, and the spaces in-between artworks)? The following is a generous and thought-provoking walk through not only a series of artists’ works in the Biennial, but also through a set of approaches and questions that continue to fuel Fan’s ongoing inquiry around the role of collectivity, discontinuity, and meaning-making.

title: Flourish and Unfold
body: Caitlin Taguibao was born in Toronto where she is a gardener, illustrator, and mural painter. She enjoys being outside and working with her hands and has spent time working in urban gardens and organic farms. Using bright colours, her murals aim to provide warm, inviting moments to appreciate the beauty of nature. Her work is inspired by plant lore and personal stories, exploring moments of self-reflection and growth. She has worked with other artists both locally and internationally, and held her first solo exhibition Leaves and Remains at KRACK! Studio & Gallery in Yogyakarta. Her work can be seen throughout the city, where reciprocal nourishing relationships grow over time.
field_article_contents:
Caitlin Taguibao, Flourish and Unfold (2019), mural. Courtesy of the artist. To explore the mural, use the +/- buttons on the top left of the window to zoom in and out, or click and scroll left or right to see the more with your cursor. 
Caitlin Taguibao in front of Flourish and Unfold (2019), installed in the TBA Programs Hub. Photo courtesy of the artist.
field_editorial:
Caitlin Taguibao has a diverse practice as a gardener, illustrator and muralist. Her work is concerned with environmental and social ecologies, and is rooted in collaborative relationships that build up over long periods of time, with other artists, community members, youth, plant life, as well as non-living beings. Her work can be seen throughout the city, where reciprocal, nourishing relationships grow over time. 

Flourish and Unfold (2019), a mural commissioned by the Biennial for the Programs Hub and located in the middle of Toronto’s industrial waterfront landscape, explores new ways of being and living that relate to the behaviours of mycelial networks. As horizontal systems, they nourish the living with the residue of the past. They are a communicative and symbiotic ecology imbued with generosity. Mushrooms as the fruiting bodies of hidden mycelial networks appeared throughout the various rooms of the Programs Hub. These exposed mycelial networks enveloped the walls, reminding the space's inhabitants of the collaborative relational ethos and values to be carried throughout ongoing workshops, discussions, and community gatherings.

Similar to the way the mural held us generously, Caitlin’s mycelial network appears throughout this publication to remind us to think about the possibilities of invisible connections that extend expansively and even cosmologically.

title: Function Follows Use: Gendai Mobile Unit
body: Born and raised in Shanghai, Yan Wu moved to Canada in 2001 and currently lives in Toronto. She holds a Master of Visual Studies, Curatorial Studies, from the University of Toronto. Between 2010 and 2012, she acted as the Director of Programming at the Gendai Gallery and subsequently stayed on the board’s programming committee until 2019. Currently she is the Public Art Curator for the City of Markham. In 2016, she was the Curator-in-Residence at the Art Museum at the University of Toronto and in 2015 Assistant Curator for the inaugural Shanghai Urban Space Art Season. As a translator, she has collaborated with artist James Carl in completing the Chinese translation of Rosalind Krauss’s Passages in Modern Sculpture (2016), Lucy Lippard’s Six Years and Dan Graham’s Rock My Religion (2018), John Cage’s Not Wanting to Say Anything About Marcel (2020), and Formless by Yves-Alain Bois and Rosalind Krauss (2021). Her writing appears in Canadian and Chinese art and architecture publications including artforum.cn, ArtReview Asia, Canadian Art, and PUBLIC. Commissioned by the M+ Museum in Hong Kong, she is currently working on an online interactive about Marcel Duchamp’s Boîte-en-valise.
field_article_contents:
Alexandre David, Gendai Mobile Unit (2011), commissioned by Gendai Gallery and Yam Lau. Image courtesy of Gendai Gallery.

It reinforces the idea that the meaning is plainly in view, apparent when the work is “used.” There is nothing deliberately obscure, hidden behind the work’s implementation. Being “used” is the sole condition that transpires the work’s purpose. No discursive rhetoric or promotional clamor is required here.—Yam Lau, "Alexandre David, Embedded Futures" (2011)

The Gendai Mobile Unit by Montreal artist Alexandre David was commissioned in 2011 by Gendai and guest artist Yam Lau who was a board member at the time. In response to Gendai’s gradual transformation into a mobile organization, the unit was conceived as an operational strategy and exploratory exercise in exhibition, production, and forms of communication in and around the art community. It deploys inventive implementations to activate and animate various host sites. The specs of this functional unit can be articulated as storage, seating, and a presentation platform in various configurations and permutations by responding to the vicissitudes of need and use. Over the years, it has also quietly turned into an archive, documenting the trajectory of an organization’s struggles with physical presence, ways of operation, and institutional identity.

Alexandre David, Instructional drawings for the Gendai Mobile Unit (2012), commissioned by Gendai Gallery and Yam Lau. Image courtesy of Gendai Gallery.

The unit consists of five shapes: one rectangle, two squares, one column, and one L-shape. Each component is made up of a welded metal grid and plywood sheet—David's choice material for being easy to replace and to re-use in other projects—mounted on one side or two. Upright, the plywood functions as the back support and shelf board of a bookcase, while horizontally it can be used as a table or seat. A set of industrial felt are cut into the same shapes as the plywood sheets, to be used as optional surface cover. Stacked together, the shapes form a three-layer cuboid designed to fit into a cargo van for easy transportation or storage. When the work first arrived, what David assembled included two additional parts: drawings that served as instruction manual and two boxes of tools to maximize the unit’s potential with wheels for mobility, a tarp for outdoor storage, and ratchet strap for vehicle transportation, etc.

The Gendai Mobile Unit becomes an interactive community board at Art of the Danforth (March – May 2014). Image courtesy of Gendai Gallery.

Since its completion in 2011, the Gendai Mobile Unit has travelled to Art Metropole (2012, 2016–18), the Fair of Alternative Art in Sudbury (2012), Gallery 101 in Ottawa (2012), the Toronto International Art Fair (2012), the Gendai Workstation (2012), the Art of the Danforth in Toronto (2014), and OCAD University’s Experiential Learning Program within the RBC Centre for Emerging Artists & Designers (2018–). Between these stops, the unit has parked in Gendai board members’ basements, backyards, and garages. In action, it has performed as the furniture to support a space for reading and discussion, the kitchen for a mobile feast, and as the back extension of a car to allow for a lemonade stand that encouraged commerce and community gathering. It has also been featured protagonist in Gendai’s Indiegogo campaign, and the conceptual platform for Gendai mobile projects such as Model Minority (2013–14) and Gendai Kitchen (2016–17). Most importantly, it has shaped Gendai’s transition into an initiative: a virtual space that gathers the likeminded and encourages experimental programming.

By now, the Gendai Mobile Unit has been in “use” for eight years. Putting quotation marks around the term “use” has nothing to do with irony. Rather, the emphasis here is to deliver a sense of wonder: the unit’s reticence as an artwork and its openness as a functional object/space.

A collaborative presentation between the Gendai Mobile Unit and Art Metropole at Art Toronto (2012). Photo by Yan Wu.
The Gendai Mobile Unit hosted at OCAD University Centre for Emerging Artists and Designers (2019). Photo by Shellie Zhang.
field_editorial:
Founded in 2000, Gendai Gallery is a Toronto-based art organization that supports contemporary practices—primarily by East Asian artists and artists of colour. Gendai has transformed many times over the last two decades, exploring various organizational models and methodologies, where the gallery breathes and responds like a living organism; the function and purpose of the gallery is shaped by the needs of the moment, responding to changing situations. Operating as a collective rather than a hierarchical organization, Gendai was built upon a shared ethos, interests, and conversations, where strong friendships have blossomed. Since 2011, they have been mobile. Their history of experimentation with collective models and practices of reconfigurability, collaboration, and adaptability are reflected in recent projects involving film, modular furniture, publications, treehouse dinner parties, newspapers, screenings, haikus, neighbourhood survey actions, a lemonade stand, musical jingles, and collective readings.

Our curatorial intentions and visions in creating the Programs Hub at the Biennial aligned strongly with Gendai’s history of generating playful, alternative methodologies for co-existence in seeking new ways of being together. Gendai Mobile Unit is a functional artwork by Alexandre David, commissioned by Gendai and artist Yam Lau in 2011 when the gallery went mobile. The work became the gallery’s host and carries all of its momentary needs—flexible seating, presentation and storage space, with measurements made to fit a single cargo van for transport. Over the years, the work has travelled to multiple sites—a community centre, Art Metropole, various galleries, OCAD University, and in 2019, it became a core aspect of the Biennial’s Programs Hub, not as “furniture” but enacting spatial methodologies of gathering, reading, generous hosting, and sharing. Being able to have this work in our Programs Hub allows for a practice of returning daily, and responding generously to co-create a sense of belonging and futurity together. Over a period of three months, Gendai Mobile Unit hosted us with care, to meet all of our momentary needs, to play, to rest, to read, to provoke, to share, in some cases to have a (synthesized) campfire around. It held space for practices of spontaneous, collaborative, and reciprocal methodologies and embodied a collective ethos.

The following text by Yan Wu republished from 2019 reflects on the history of the Unit and methodologies around its conception.

body: Borelson is a multidisciplinary artist and creative director based in Toronto. After a multilingual upbringing in central Africa (Gabon, Congo), he went on to spend some years in France following some disruptive family events, before relocating to Canada by himself. His unique music is mostly hip-hop and afrofusion infused, mixed with other music influences such as jazz, classical music, and gospel. After a mixtape (2014) and an EP (2016), Borelson released his debut LP As Far As Eye Can See (2020) along with a docuseries about the success stories of immigrants and first-gen Canadians, both projects inspired by the quote, “I didn’t come this far to only come this far” and the power of visualization. Borelson’s creations revolve around the concept of afrofuturism and the Ubuntu philosophy, aiming to give more drive, hope, and a sense of collective freedom through mutual respect and balance. As an explorer and bridge builder between communities across the universe, Borelson has performed in Paris, London, Miami, Austin (SXSW 2018), Ghana (Year of Return), as well as Montreal and Toronto (Afrofest, Nuit Blanche, Toronto Biennale of Art, RBC Music virtual showcases, Fashion Art Toronto, among others). His shows—whether solo or with a live band—always bring high vibrational energy and are worth attending.

field_editorial: “Every Story Matters”—these words resonated throughout the space of the Art Gallery of York University (AGYU) as spoken-word poet, musician, and director Borelson moved between the works of artists Jae Jarrell and Caecilia Tripp with groups of participants. From our first meeting it was clear that Borelson’s ongoing interdisciplinary work around place-making, writing, and Afrofuturism—shared through a cosmos of interwoven voices and geographies—would challenge us to reconsider our own relationships to and histories of the land and narratives we inhabit. The following is an annotated script of Borelson’s generative offering as part of TBA’s Storytelling program (2019–), including a further layering of annotations, links to his ongoing music practice, and an invitation to continue the journey.
